body:
I strongly oppose this suggestion. IMO this is the culmination of several
well meaning and well reasoned changes to the language and its tools that
have resulted in a less cohesive and more complex whole. Specifically:

1. internal/ packages encourage a proliferation of a taxonomy of tiny
little packages with poor names and divided responsibilities.
2. this alias proposal permits the package author to continue in this
fashion, then smoosh them all back together into an idiomatic _looking_ top
level package.

People will go hog wild with this feature creating byzantine levels of
complex intertwined packages then cover that all up with a thick layer of
aliiasing (cpp's #define comes sharply to mind, Fortran's EQUIVALENCE is
another)

I cannot express how strongly I do not wish to see this alias feature
implemented in the language.

On Fri, Jul 22, 2016 at 10:09 AM, Minux Ma <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> On Thu, Jul 21, 2016 at 8:03 PM, Dave Cheney <notifications@github.com>
> wrote:
>
> > server is a bad name for a package, client is also a bad name for a
> > package.
>
>
> I have explicitly said "multiple internal packages". I don't think
> client/common/server are bad name for an internal package under net/http.
>
> Let me be more specific, in my net/http example, I propose that we break
> net/http into:
>
> net/http: use type alias to export types from the following internal
> packages
> net/http/internal/common: Request, Response etc.
> net/http/internal/server client side only logic
> net/http/internal/client server side only logic
> net/http/internal/http2: vendored copy of x/net/http2
>
> (For http2, we can do the same, but to support older Go versions, we can't
> do the break yet.)
>
>
> On Fri, Jul 22, 2016 at 10:01 AM, Minux Ma <notifications@github.com>
> wrote:
> >
> > > Perhaps it's better to point out a few packages that really benefit
> from
> > > refactoring with the help of type aliases. I think net/http is one of
> > them.
> > >
> > > If we could break it into multiple internal packages, say, one for
> common
> > > logic, one for client and another for server, I'd expect we can
> properly
> > > vendor http2 into net/http without the current bundle hack. (search
> > > "[golang-dev] http -> http2 -> http import cycle" for the email.)
> >
